newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electric futures seen opening flat to lower.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electric futures seen opening flat to lower.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures were called to open flat to lower Wednesday, continuing recent weakness in power and natural gas prices in the western U.S. due to persistent mild weather.
"I don't see how it's going to stay up," said a Houston trader.

In early over-the-counter (OTC), December Palo Verde (PV) futures were talked at $20.60-$21.00 a megawatt hour (MWh) against a Tuesday settlement of $21.05. December OTC California-Oregon Border (COB) futures were discussed at $22.25-$23.50 versus a close of $23.05.
December natgas delivered to the San Juan/Blanco Hub was last quoted near $2.35 per million British thermal units, flat from late Tuesday's quote.
"The weather forecast is bearish for the next two weeks," said a New York-based broker.

For Thursday, the Pacific Northwest was forecast to experience temperatures peaking in 40s-50s Fahrenheit range and bottoming in the 20s-40s, while the Southwest peaking in 60s-80s and bottoming in 30s-50s.

Extended outlook indicated Northwest's temperatures would stay near seasonal norms through Friday with clouds and showers moving into the region. Southwest's weather would be normal to above-normal through Friday.
